It takes a while before you all start to calm down. There is nothing you can do about the swap, so it was time to assess what should happen next.

You are probably the luckiest one. Jackie had been accepted to college in the fall as an undeclared major. Her life -- you life now -- was pretty much an open book for you. Sure, she has some high school friends, an upcoming prom, and graduation, but you had been through all that before. High school friends fade and get replaced by college friends. Surprisingly, no one had asked Jackie to prom yet.

Ken is a little more uncomfortable with his new situation in life, but he realizes it's probably not going to be the worst either. Phillipa pulls in a pretty good salary, gets this excellent suite, and she's single, completely independent. The big negative for him is losing so much youth.

Jim is not comfortable with the fact that he has two small children to take care of and breastfeed, not to mention a husband now that he's in Ada's body. He thinks about skipping out on all of it, but he is starting to feel some internal conflict because of the maternal instincts lingering in his new body.

Phillipa realizes she's in about the same position as Jim. She can easily do his job, collect his paycheck, and live a happy life. Of course, she'll have much more of it to live now!

The three of you had to drive around the parking lots and beachside streets for the better part of an hour. Ken finally stopped at a parking meter next to a house with a yard overgrown in weeds.

“OK ladies, everyone out! Let’s see if Phillippa has any coins lying around here.” He said, reaching and fumbling in the compartments and pockets of the car.

What happens next?
1141122121.title: Getting situated at the beach

choices: The men get something to eat
11411221211.content:
The moment you placed the phone back in the purse, the ringtone went off. Someone was trying to call Jackie! You would have panicked had the number not shown “Bill” in the caller ID! You don’t think you could do a good job impersonating Jackie, and frankly you hope you won’t have to either.

“Hello?” You answered the phone. The high-pitched voice coming out of your mouth made you feel strange, as did hearing your old voice coming out of the sender.

“Hi, this is Bill right?” Ada’s words came out of your body over the line in partially broken English.

“Yes, hello Ada.” You said. “What’s going on?”

“That’s what I want to ask you. Is Jim taking care of my body?” She asked gingerly.

You looked for Ken and Jim before replying in the affirmative. The conversation felt stultified to say the least. While you felt calm talking to Ada, she was the opposite. Perhaps this was too much for a twenty-six year old mother to go through at one time. You tried to reassure her that things would turn out okay, even though you had trouble believing it yourself. You didn’t even know Ada and she doesn’t know you; somehow you both had been cast together in some hiccup of the universe beyond comprehension. It’s probably not that dramatic, but damned if you know why this happened.

The conversation started and stopped with dead air in between. You found out that the women checked themselves in to the hotel in the room facing the parking lot. Phillippa (as Jim) and Jackie (as Ken) went out for some groceries to stock up. Ada was researching possible solutions on how to get everyone back to normal. But the Internet was like a foreign land to her. It was then that she called you. You filled her in on your half of the details and suggested that you meet up again to make a plan. It was only a suggestion, of course, but Ada sounded much more relieved afterwards.

As you put the phone away for the second time, you saw Ken and Jim get out of the water. It was later in the afternoon now, and some of the beachgoers had begun to leave. A part of you felt surprised that nobody approached you – not even any of the boys, the thought blinked into your head. Where did that come from?

By the time Jim and Ken padded up to the camp, they had mostly dried off. You could see goosebumps rippling across Ken’s arms and back. Jim’s hair had been soaked, so it dried into that windblown, stringy look.

“My god that was an experience.” Jim said, adjusting his bikini before grabbing a towel.

“Yes, but enough of that for today.” Ken cut him off.

“So, did you enjoy sitting around this afternoon Bill?” asked Jim.

“Uhh, it was interesting to say the least.” You shrugged in reply.

“Do you know where the restrooms are, Bill? This body really has to pee.” Ken stated, visibly trying to hold it in.

“Why didn’t you just go in the ocean?” Jim laughed, “That’s what I did.”

“Dude, that’s so gross! You told me that warm spot was from the kids next to us!” Ken fumed, his Russian outburst an oddity coming from the body of the black woman.

“When you gotta go…”

“No! Do that when you’re five years old, not twenty-two!”

“Actually, this body is twenty-six years old.”

“Whatever. Where is the bathroom Bill?” You pointed Ken to the restrooms, and he hurried off in that direction.

You turned on Jim. “You asshole, Ada called me while you were out pissing yourself. She asked me if you were taking good care of her body. She’s terrified of this whole ordeal.”

Jim paused for a moment, his manner becoming more sobered. “Yeah. I guess I uh, just let myself get out of control.” He added, “I shouldn’t have felt her body up while she was there.”

“It’s no big deal. When we get swapped back we’ll all have a nice laugh afterwards.” You concluded.

Ken returned to your group, and you changed back out of your swimsuit and into Jackie's original clothes minus the blazer and hose. You all packed the things back into bags and put them back into the Bentley. The sun was beginning its descent now, the sky turning a picturesque orange-blue. This was the stuff of vacations, you thought.

Well, almost.


What happens next?
11411221211.title: Ada calls you

114112212111.content:
You return to the resort, and Ken and Jim decide they want to hit the beach again. But you had agreed to meet Ada. You let them go and head down to the lobby.

You see Ada with a suitcase in her hand. She tells you that she and Jackie put together some clothes for you and Jim, each sneaking into their houses while no one was around. You thank her politely and go with her to drop the suitcase off in your room.

She asks if you might want to change into something from the suitcase, since she notices you've been wearing the blouse and pencil skirt all day. You go to the bathroom and strip naked once more, then you open the suitcase and look inside.

As you do so, a hand reaches around and grabs your breast. You yelp.

"Sorry, I didn't mean to startle you." Ada says, "Just relax. It'll feel good if you relax." She starts to fondle your breast.

You are too afraid to say anything just yet. The whole situation makes you feel uncomfortable. Ada takes her other hand and pulls something out of the suitcase. It is some sexy lingerie.

"Why don't you wear this?" She asks you.

"I...I'm not comfortable." You respond.

"Aren't you curious?" She asks, "Plus, who better to share your first time with than your own body? Come on, let me pop your cherry."

You cannot believe this! Ada is trying to have sex with you!
114112212111.title: Check in with the women

choices: Leave the restaurant with your friends
114112212112.content:
The three young men-turned-women left the beach, with Ken driving, Jim in the front passenger seat, and you in the back seat with the beach supplies and hotel garb.

Although you had ignored it for the last hour, Jackie’s stomach started growling. You haven’t eaten anything in Jackie’s body in the several hours since switching with her. No doubt Ken and Jim were hungry as well; they probably burned more energy at the beach today than you did.

Ken was the one who broke the silence, however. “Hey guys, I’m feeling pretty hungry. You want to stop somewhere to eat?” He turned the car toward what appeared to be the business district of this resort town.

“Let’s go to a bar. After a day like this, I could really have a drink.” Jim suggested, scanning the available stores and restaurants packed alongside the road.

“Jackie can’t go to a bar, dude.” Ken said. “She’s eighteen and the legal drinking age is older than that. Bill wouldn’t make it past the entrance.”

“There’s probably a non-drinking section or something. It’s worth a shot.” Jim persisted.

“No, it’s really not.” Ken said, his eyes remaining focused on the road. “Even so, your body should go without alcohol if you’re planning to breastfeed.”

“Let’s go to a restaurant?” You interjected, perceiving that another retort by Jim was going to send Ken over the edge again. The three of you agreed upon a seafood restaurant; the parking lot was full which was a good sign. It also had a deck overlooking the ocean.

Ken pulled up to the main curb, giving the keys to the valet parking staff. The three of you placed your names on the wait list and sat down on a bench outside, having to cross your legs because of the skirt. Thankfully, this restaurant accepted all kinds of customers, from the elegantly dressed honeymooners to the surfing bums. You three fit right in. It only took a few minutes for an attendant to guide your group to a table out on the deck.

The remaining sunlight danced off the water and flirted with the horizon. The lit candles at the table flickered at the breeze, and you observed some of the other restaurant patrons as well. Observation had always been something of a corollary to your naturally inquisitive demeanor.

Sitting in the corner was a man with a white beard and a fishing hat who read the newspaper. At another table were an older-looking mother and father with their rambunctious kids. Some other girls sat at a table near you, but they looked too old to be in high school. If you were still in your old body, you might have stopped to try a pickup line or two. You thought about these things silently to yourself.

A waiter appeared and took your orders. For drinks, Ken decided to go big and have a shot of hard liqueur. Jim conscientiously chose a non-alcoholic beverage, and you did the same but for a different reason of course. As entrees, you three ordered those buckets of seafood which are steamed and cooked in the pot. It was most definitely more than your body could hope to eat, but as long as Ken was charging it to Phillippa’s credit card you couldn’t complain.

Dinner progressed without much conversation, only the clattering and chiming of silverware was heard. Jim retold some of his bawdier jokes which helped to lighten the mood. The food tasted satisfactory and the music had a sticky Reggae feel to it. Before long, the waiter returned again to the table.

Expecting the check, Ken started fishing for Phillippa’s card within her purse. However, the waiter informed you that the check had already been paid for – complements of the gentleman over there, the waiter gestured toward a corner of the deck. It was the bearded fisherman, who now was smoking a cigar and leaning against the railing of the deck, looking out to sea.

“Wow that was nice of him.”

“Umm… do you think we should go thank him?” You asked, seeing your friends start to get up to leave.

“Nah, he looks preoccupied with something at the moment. Don’t want to bother him.” Ken answered, brushing some crumbs off Phillippa’s dress. “Let’s go.”

You are torn between what to do. Gratitude would dictate that you approach the man and acknowledge his generosity for paying for your moderately expensive dinner. But being a young woman fitting the gender role and trying to blend in as well as possible, you thought such an action might appear too forward. Plus, you have no idea who the guy is and what his intentions might be. What do you do?
114112212112.title: The men get something to eat

1141122121122.content:
You felt bad about not approaching the man. Such acts of generosity rarely occur anymore, and they should be recognized and appreciated for what they are. In an ordinary circumstance you would have done it, but you and your friends had more pressing concerns. As you catch up to your friends, you look out to the deck again. You couldn’t see him.

Before you leave, you have to use the bathroom. Ken and Jim agree to wait outside with the valet staff as you walk down the hallway leading to the bathrooms. Of course, it would be inappropriate to do anything but enter the door with the Ladies insignia posted on it.

Your heart beat in your chest in a Jackie-like fluttery rhythm. Fortunately, there were no other women to be seen, so you chose a stall and locked the door. Not surprisingly, the toilets appeared in better condition than the ones you remember in the Men’s rooms. Nevertheless, to avoid catching any diseases you spread some toilet paper over the seat. Letting Jackie’s skirt and panties fall down to her ankles, you sat down.

It seemed like an eternity; in Jackie’s body you found it harder to go when you focused on what you were doing. The bathrooms were quiet. You cleared your mind, allowing it to take you away from this situation to some other comfortable place… an emotional numbing of sorts. Before you knew it, you heard the sound of urine splashing against the inside of the toilet. Identifying the muscles involved, you learned to control them better. Thinking about this no more, you made sure to wipe and flush before redressing, washing your hands, and exiting the bathroom and restaurant.

The valet service pulled Phillipa’s Bentley up to the curb. Ken left a handsome tip and climbed into the car. Then you were off again.

“So… where do we go from here?” You asked, taking in the scenery of nightfall in this exotic landscape.

“Ada told me that she normally gets off of work about this time.” Jim replied. “If I have to fill her life role for the night, that means I have to go to her house.” He bit his lip before adding, “To her husband and children.”

“Have you thought about skipping?” asked Ken.

“What do you mean?”

“Skipping as in: Not going to her house and instead crashing with me in my hotel suite tonight?” Ken suggested.

“No, thanks for the offer though.” Jim shook his head, Ada’s hair trembling slightly back and forth. An odd smile formed on his face. “I need to spend some quality time with Jorge!”

“Want me to drop you off at the hotel?” Ken asked, finding a great pleasure in being able to drive a nice car wherever he wanted. “How does Ada commute?”

“Bus.” Jim muttered. “Swing by this neighborhood over here and drop me off. This is where Ada lives.”

You looked out the window at a modest-looking series of houses. They all looked built by hand but not in any way to indicate shabby construction. The houses were small; one-story, external garage, short brick and adobe walls separating neighbors. The front yard was also small but you could tell it was well loved. A red tricycle lied on its side next to a metal swing set. The grasses were tall and green and sparkled with dew in the moonlight.

Jim said good night, and you took his place sitting in the front passenger seat. You were again reminded of Jackie’s short stature, as the dashboard and seat felt much bigger now. On the positive side, you now had more leg room!

“Are you going to Jackie’s home too, or are you staying with me tonight?” Ken asked.

You pondered this for a moment, and something about this confused you. Why have Jackie’s parents not called her, asking where she is? Granted, this is about the time when her shift ends (or so she told you). If Jackie doesn’t own her own car – which you believe is rather unlikely – then she has to get home from work somehow. Could she take the bus like Ada does? You have her address scrawled on a piece of paper in her purse. It might take a while to pinpoint exactly where she lives, but unless you’ve got a better idea you will have to face her family at some point.

As you weigh your options, a slow, creeping sense of dread washes over you. You ignore it as best you can; it’s the elephant in the room, the question everyone was thinking. “What if I never switch back?”
1141122121122.title: Leave the restaurant with your friends

choices: The next morning is a school day
11411221211221.content:
You look at your phone and see there are 17 missed calls. The ringer must have gotten turned off! You figure you have no choice but to return to Jackie's home.

The house isn't far away from Ada's, and when you walk in the door, Jackie's parents just start yelling you in a language you didn't understand. You run upstairs to get away from them. Luckily, Jackie had photos of her and her friends on the door, so you were able to figure out which room was hers. You change into a t-shirt and jeans. It's much more comfortable than the clothes you've been wearing.

Before long, you notice a girl a few years younger than Jackie standing there. You guessed that this was Jackie's sister even though she hadn't mentioned a sister. "Mom and Dad are pissed at you for being late," She said.

"I worked late. It's fine."

"Nuh-uh. My friends totally saw you on the beach today. You were skipping."

"Mrs. Jones asked me to do some research for the guests. Didn't you see her with me? It took longer than expected." You thought of this as a brilliant lie.

Jackie's sister glares at you before storming off. You sigh with relief.
11411221211221.title: Try to find Jackie's home

114112212112211.content:
You watch Jackie’s sister go downstairs before closing the door. The first thing to do is process the onslaught of new and unfamiliar perceptions and insights.

Before doing anything, it is best to think of a goal for the night. You wonder just how you can escape interacting with Jackie’s parents, and hopefully her sister as well, before morning. From what her sister told you, you inferred that Jackie’s parents had strict expectations of when their daughters should arrive home each day. They didn’t seem to berate you upon entering the house, allowing you to flee upstairs into Jackie’s bedroom unbothered. Will there be a parental lecture later tonight? Or is there a sufficient level of guilt that the Wu’s expect Jackie to realize her wrongdoing and apologize to them first? Either scenario will involve facing her parents, a task that you aren’t sure you can handle yet. Is cutting work and being late home even a big deal? Your blood stirred with a strange vibe of rebelliousness.

Then there is the wild card, Jackie’s sister. It was difficult to decipher exactly how the two girls got along together. Having grown up with both a brother and a sister, you knew your siblings like the back of your hand. But that was when you were Bill, of course, and interactions from brother to brother, or even brother to sister, may have entirely different contexts than interactions between two sisters. Jackie’s sister also mentioned that her friends noticed you at the beach today. Since the two girls differed a few years in age, it was unlikely that they might hang out at school together. This means that Jackie’s sister must bring her friends home occasionally; it would allow them enough time to be able to recognize Jackie on a crowded beach during the summer. This might compound your problems a bit, but if you can somehow win over Jackie’s sister – maybe even tell her everything about who you really are and what is happening – your situation might improve. She might be able to help you. You make sure to store this away for future consideration. It all depends on how well they get along together and how good and trustworthy Jackie’s sister is at keeping secrets.

Next, you decide to familiarize yourself with your surroundings. Jackie’s room is small but compact; whatever nook or cranny seemed to have extra space she found something to place there. Jackie’s bed was just the right size for her, although it would have been way too short for your old body. The comforters, bed sheet, and pillowcase all had a flowery, spring motif to them. Articles of Jackie’s clothing hung carelessly from the wooden bedposts, as if she intended to wear them around the house later. On her carpet lay her backpack, a lavender colored towel, some glamour magazines, and a string of beads. Posters had been tacked onto her walls... mostly Asian boy bands with foreign lettering on them, but there was one WWF poster that you recognized.

You flip through the notebooks in her backpack. Apparently, despite being in a position to earn that scholarship, Jackie was struggling in a few of her classes. No doubt that her coursework and job schedule (as well as any other extracurricular activities she was doing right now) left her with little free time. Examining further the cause of her academic troubles, you were delighted to find that she was studying basic Physics and Calculus! Easy courses for an Engineering major, you thought to yourself, but not so easy for a high school student. The other classes interested you less, as they rounded out the schedule for a typical high school student and were subjects you had slept through once already.

Glancing around the room, you notice a small bookcase that also acted as Jackie’s nightstand. The furniture in her room was mahogany brown in color and looked old. The nightstand had a lamp on top of it in addition to a laptop computer, books and papers, and some other junk. The bookcase was lined with all kinds of hard covers and paperbacks, and you could identify romance genres, drama, even the occasional science fiction. While most of the titles disinterested you, you recognized a few popular series like the one with that wizard boy, the girl with the vampire, and another series whose author had died before its ending.

Finally, you turn to the clothes dresser, upon which lay a vanity mirror and an array of cosmetics and tubes of makeup. Deciding not to invade Jackie’s personal life any more than absolutely necessary, you skimmed over most of these things, only desiring to know where you needed to find each type of clothing. Staring into her mirror, you got another glimpse of her face staring back at you, mimicking your every move. Her closet was stuffed with more clothing, ranging from jeans to dresses to large hats to suits and a few pairs of shoes.

Absorbed in trying to learn more about Jackie’s life, you nearly jumped out of your skin when you heard a sound coming from the door! What is it?
114112212112211.title: Spending the night

choices: "What's up, Jackie? You seem different lately..."
1141122121122111.content:
You heard a scratching sound coming from the other side of the door.

“Mewmew!” The cat practically pressed its face against the barrier, as you rushed to open the door.

In strode a grey tabby cat, pawing its way confidently into the room. The cat had streaked patterns that reminded you of something like a grey zebra with large whiskers. You had never owned a cat before because you were severely allergic to them. Now, you realized, it wasn’t such a problem.

The cat leaped onto Jackie’s bed, circling it a couple of times before resting on its haunches. You weren’t sure whether to approach the creature or give it space. Cats are just like humans, you remember your girlfriend from high school saying. They each have their own peculiar personality, and they don’t live by any rules except their own. Needless to say, you had been a dog person for most of your life.

Before you could do anything, however, the cat shot straight upward, frozen in its place. It was staring at you. No, that’s not quite right. It was staring through you!

An invisible wave of some sort washed over the cat. It hissed, arching its feline incisors in what you assumed was its ‘angry face’. The cat bolted down from the bed, galloping out of the room and down the stairs. Moments later, Jackie’s sister returned up the stairs, cradling the cat in her arms like a baby.

“Jackie? What happened to Tama? He looks downright scared!” She exclaimed, petting the cat on its head and behind the ears. The damned thing was purring again, but you could tell its yellow-marble eyes glinted with something unsettling whenever it looked your way.

“Uhh, I don’t know. He must have seen a ghost or something.” You muttered lamely, standing awkwardly in the doorway in front of Jackie’s sister.

“I heard Tama poking at your door a few minutes ago. Are you sure you didn’t do something to scare him?” Jackie’s sister persisted.

“Not at all, sis. I don’t know what happened.”

“Tama rarely gets spooked at home…”

"He did this time, I have no idea why."

Jackie’s sister slowly let Tama, the grey tabby cat, down. He scampered down the hallway and out of sight. She appeared to be deep in thought.
1141122121122111.title: Tama, the cat

11411221211221112.content:
“Cats will be cats, I guess.”

Jackie’s sister frowned, staring down the hallway with her hands on her hips. She started to go back downstairs and then stopped.

“Will you be joining us tonight?” She asked sharply. You found yourself making some excuse about schoolwork, and surprisingly the teenage girl bought it. She left, but not before giving you a peculiar look. You closed the door once again, breathing a sigh of relief.

“That could have gotten out of hand.” You think aloud. “I should play things close to the vest until I can get out of here. I cannot rouse any more suspicion or act out of character. If only I knew how Jackie regularly acts around her friends and family!”

The remainder of the night turned out to be less stressful than you anticipated. Jackie had been procrastinating much of her schoolwork, evidently the result of burning out at the end of the school year. You checked her planner; all that remained were a few weeks of school until summer break that June. That means prom, final exams, and maybe a group project thrown somewhere in between. Manageable.

You sat on Jackie’s bed and let her legs extend down the side (her feet didn’t quite touch the floor).

While you are living in Jackie’s life, the kind thing would be to help her in any way you can. Since she is probably having difficulties adjusting to Ken’s life, you feel obligated not to wreck hers. As for the others (including Ada occupying your life), you could only hope for the best. Heck, what if Jackie swaps back into her life to find it improved? Better than before? This experience might end up leaving some people better off. You could do that!

Since Jackie did not have a TV set in her room, you found another way to drown out all other sensory reminders of your current predicament. Plugging her iPod earbuds into your ears, you attempted to find some good music to listen to while you focus on Jackie’s work. Her taste in music is a lot different, of course, but some of the bands and artists in her playlist were acceptable. Her textbooks and course material were also things that, while undemanding to a person of your level of education, required you to reach back into the rusty corner of your brain to remember. Some pieces of information are worthless after high school, yet teachers will tell you that it’s important!

While doing the work, you flipped through Jackie’s notebook. You tried to emulate her style of handwriting, in case her teachers care about things like “academic integrity” and assume someone else did her work. Copying her letters was a tedious process, as Jackie apparently loved to draw hearts over the I’s and curve her letters in a showy fashion. Also distracting were her fingernails; they shined with the gloss of a recent manicure.

Jackie also enjoyed doodling in the margins of her notebook. Flowers, spirals, and embellished names of some boys in her classes adorned the pages. Most frequent was one boy’s name: Scott Bowman. That might be a name to remember, you think.

Stretching your arms, you throw the books and papers back into Jackie’s backpack. That’s enough for one night.

Next up, you walk along the upstairs hallway to the bathroom. After using the toilet again, you then wash your hands and brush your teeth. It felt weird to use Jackie’s toothbrush, but how could you know you weren’t using her sister’s by mistake? You rinse your mouth and wash your face, deciding to leave Jackie’s hair alone. In the cabinets below the sinks were other toiletries: tissues, sunscreen, lip balm, hair curlers, razors, tampons, Maxi pads, hand lotion, toilet paper… the essential products for two normal teenage girls. You notice a hint of stubble on Jackie’s legs, meaning that she will need to shave there in a few days.

Walking back to her room, you adjust the bra straps which had been digging into your shoulders. Of course, you hadn’t forgotten about that sensation! Admittedly though, it did provide a good support for Jackie’s back in not having to deal with the unrestricted bouncing of flesh. You push these thoughts to the back of your mind. No need to get too comfortable with this body!


What happens next, if anything?
11411221211221112.title: "Cats will be cats, I guess..."

114112212112212.content:
When you wake up the next morning, you almost forgot what had happened, but Jackie's body is a quick reminder of everything. You sigh, knowing that today is a Monday, and Jackie had to go off to school. There wasn't much left to the semester, but you didn't want to risk Jackie's college scholarship and your way out of all this.

You rush through a shower, still not quite ready to explore Jackie's body too intimately, then start looking through Jackie's closet for something to wear. You had just thrown on the jeans and t-shirt last night, but you feel like throwing on something a bit more fashionable for school. You are not sure why; it just feels like the right thing to do.

You pick out another t-shirt, a knee-length skirt, and some tights. You pause before leaving Jackie's room, and place some jewelry on. It's cheap stuff that an 18-year-old girl would wear, but, heck, that's what you are now. You finish off the look with some ankle boots with a slight heel. You admire yourself in the mirror, and realize that despite being a little stuffy looking in work clothes, Jackie's actually pretty hip looking most of the time. At least, you look so today.

You bop downstairs actually sort of happy, grab an apple, and head off to class.

When you arrive at school, you notice a few girls snickering at you. It happens a few more times.

A girl approaches you. She acts pretty shocked but concerned. You are guessing she is one of Jackie's friends.

"Tell me it's not true." She says.

"What?" You ask, haven't absolutely no clue.

"The rumors." She pauses, "About you and your boss having a lesbian relationship."

"WHAT!?" You ask louder.

"Yeah, everyone is talking about how someone saw you guys at the beach yesterday, at a restaurant last night, and how she drove you home. It's totes weird."
114112212112212.title: The next morning is a school day

choices: Get away from this girl talking your ear off
Tell her you'll agree to go to prom with Hank
1141122121122121.content:
"Oh, God, don't remind me. She made us go on this thing for work. One of the maids went too. You know, see what tourists do and junk." You realize that you might have to cut off hanging with Ken and Jim until summer starts in a few weeks. You just don't want to have to deal with the rumor mill at Jackie's school like this. You just want to keep a low profile until June graduation, and then you never have to see these people ever again.

"Thank GAWD!" The girl continued, "That must've been totes embarrassing for you, hanging out with the olds is creepy."

"I survived." You shrugged.

"I guess. But we need to do damage control, Girl. Have you thought any more about Hank's invitation to the prom. You've been putting off answering him, and we could squash this if you tell him yes."

"Prom? I don't know. I'm not sure I feel like going..."

"Are you feeling okay? You've been dreaming about prom since we were like six! You've had your dress for months! And, okay, I know you could do better than Hank, so I totally understand your hesitation, but, you know, like, you need to lock down a dude for that. And, honestly, he's not that bad."
1141122121122121.title: Think of an excuse

11411221211221211.content:
"I just feel like I've grown up a lot recently thinking about college and everything," You start to form your excuse, "Prom is just starting to seem like a silly kid thing, you know?"

"Oh, God, you ARE having a lesbian affair with your boss, aren't you?" The girl asks point blank, "It's okay, you can tell me. Or do you forget I'm your best friend? Or maybe you have a new best friend, if you catch my drift." She winks at you.

"No, it's not that..." You desperately just want to end this conversation, "...don't we need to get to class?"

"Yeah, I guess so. But after History, you are SO telling me what's up!"

You sigh. There's just no shaking Jackie's friend.
11411221211221211.title: Get away from this girl talking your ear off

choices: Go visit the women in your old bodies
Call Jim and ask if he is okay
11411221211222.content:
Before you made your decision, Jackie’s cell phone started ringing again. You picked it up, dismayed to find that her mother was calling. You placed it against your ear.

“Hello? M-Mom?” You asked.

You heard the sound of a woman speaking on the other line, but absolutely none of it made sense to you!

“Gah!” You yelped, flinging the phone into the back seat. “Jackie’s mom speaks Asian!”

Ken cracked a smile at your outburst, still keeping his eyes on the road. “Asian is not a language.”

“Whatever, OK? I think it sounded Japanese or something like that. Oh nooooooo, this is bad. This is worse than I hoped! How am I going to pretend to be Jackie when I can’t even converse with her parents?” You shrieked, making Jackie’s voice sound a bit shriller than you expected.

“Looks like you’ll be staying with me tonight.” Ken said resolutely.

“Agreed!” You said. As you calmed down again, you immediately thought of Jim. Given the conversation you had earlier with Ada, it is also likely that she does not speak English at home either. As far as you knew Jim never learned Spanish; he was in for a rough night. This gives you some reassurance because it was a stroke of luck that Jackie’s mom decided to call when she did. Otherwise, you might have stumbled into a difficult situation, cultural discrepancies notwithstanding. Staying with Ken tonight will provide you with a temporary respite from Jackie’s life, overwhelming as it may turn out to be.

You and Ken arrived back at the hotel. Since Phillipa was virtually “married to the job”, she lived in a hotel suite at the same place in which she worked. Philippa would later claim this was for things like increasing productivity or reducing transportation costs (whatever that actually meant). But as soon as you entered her suite, you realized why Philippa had it so good.

“Damn, this is extravagant!” You mumbled, in open-mouthed wonder.

The suite was located on the top floor, so naturally it was the best one in the entire hotel. Think of it as the kind movie stars and famous people rent out. A plasma-screen TV hung on the wall, overlooking a small living area, a kitchen, boudoir, bed, and bathroom. The bed was the largest you’ve seen in years, or maybe this was because everything now seemed bigger from Jackie’s perspective. The bed contained soft throw pillows and pillows with real feathers in them, embroidered blankets and bedding, and a sturdy mattress. The boudoir had racks upon racks of women’s clothing and more kinds than you could fit in a catalog. Phillipa had shoes for everything, in every color. The living area had a couple of couch chairs and a dining table. The bathroom shined pearl white and had a shower, hot tub, toilet, and two sinks. The walls were dotted with oil paintings. An entire side wall was nothing but curtains covering a sliding glass door that led to an overhanging balcony. The view of the ocean rivaled none other!

“Holy shit, she’s loaded.” Ken stood dumbfounded. “This is all my stuff now!”

“Don’t get used to it…” you added quietly. He seemed not to notice.

“Bill, come check out this hot tub! Incredible!”

“Ken, you’ve got to see the ocean from here.” You motioned for him to come to you. He stood out on the balcony with you, watching the moon cast a gleam of light along the still waters.

“Jim is an idiot! He should have stayed here with us!” Ken chuckled, flipping on the TV and turning to the sports channel. He leaped into the couch chair, reclining it until he was almost parallel with the ground.

“Our old bodies could still be here at the hotel.” You mentioned, walking over next to him. “Want to go see how their day was?”

“Maybe tomorrow.” He yawned, stretching out his arms wide. “Look at that play! Kobe from downtown! Swish!”

You snickered, claiming the bed for yourself.


Later that night, you awoke to the sound of Ken running full sprint into the bathroom. You swung your slender legs out of bed, half groggy but nevertheless conscious of whose body you currently possess.

Ken closed the door behind him and turned on the light. Moments later, you heard a dry heave and the sound of a woman completely tossing her cookies. You allowed Ken some time to recover before knocking on the door.

Ken opened the door, and you recoiled with alarm! His face and upper body were swollen!

“What happened?” You asked breathlessly, staring at him in shock.

“Thellthith.” His swollen lips and tongue produced a garbled mess of sound. “Theth ullugic tuh thellthith.”

Phillipa is allergic to shellfish. The delayed reaction only took a few hours after dinner, but it took its toll on Ken’s body. He declined going to the nearby clinic, as he asserted that the worst of it was over. You kept a steady eye on him through most of the early morning in case his condition worsened. As a result, you and Ken lost a few hours of sleep last night.


You awaken next morning to the sun shining through the room. What do you do next?
11411221211222.title: Stay with Ken overnight

11413.content:
While you were standing in front of the front desk you suddenly find yourself standing behind it instead. A wave of dizziness strikes you as you somehow feel different. "What happened? You ask yourself as you hear your voice sounding much smoother somehow. Grabbing hold of the desk you see something you thought you would never see happen; the skin of your hand suddenly being a chocolate brown. Not to mention how small and slim your hands are now.

Looking down you are shocked to see the rest of your body was different as well. You could see a pair of brown feet encased in high heels with same colored legs coming from underneath a black skirt. Not to mention your chest; it looks like something has grown out of them; not to mention it feels like it's pulling you down. And at the same time you feel there is something different with your hair. It's no longer short and spiky but instead it feels long.

That's when you notice your reflection in the marble front desk. Looking back at you is the female manager that came back with that hotel receptionist Jackie. That's when it suddenly hit you: are you somehow in the body of that manager?

Looking right of you, you see that Jackie seems out of it as well. She looks at her hands and you could see her face turned...
11413.title: Phillipa

1151.content:
Your group of friends:
Bill Conway: 21, studying engineering at University, not very athletic, very curious and polite
Jim Wong: 22, working at an Airport as a baggage handler, very athletic, very outgoing and stubborn
Ken Petrov: 22, apprenticing to become an electrician, average athleticism, easily upset and serious

Swap places with: Political Candidates & their Family
Cassandra Snow: 37, the wife of a right-wing candidate, no children
Angelica Cortez: 35, the unmarried left-wing candidate, no children
Kirsten Bo: 21, the daughter of the centrist candidate, works on her Father's campaign

Who are you?
1151.title: Political Candidates & their Family

11511.content:
"Why are we here on such an awesome Saturday morning, anyway?" Jim asked, groaning aloud as the three of you entered the building. "I'd rather be working than go to a political rally. Seriously, Ken, I'm not even joking. If I'm gonna deal with peoples' baggage, I'd do it on a tarmac. For a salary."

Ken led the three of you through the double doors, down the long hallway adorned with potted plants and paintings, and up to the guest registrants table. Your shoes echoed over the granite flooring, but it got drowned out by the steadily increasing noise of people talking. "Shut up, Jim. Last night you said it was a good idea, that with such a large audience there must be at least some chicks worth bagging here to scope out."

"Yeah, and I was drunk last night too. Dude, I don't even remember saying that." He grumbled. The night before, like many Friday nights, you three went out for some socializing, nightclubbing, and finally crashing at your house. Memories beyond that were a bit foggy for Jim, who didn't pace himself and ended up blacking out on the cab ride back home. Honestly you couldn't remember if Jim had said that, or if Ken was just making it up.

"Regardless, we're here... so let's make the best of it." You interrupted, as the volunteer sitting behind the table looked up at you.

"Welcome to the Mayor's Collaborative Public Forum and Town Hall! Sign here with your name, e-mail address, and phone number for your candidate's latest updates!" Chirped the volunteer. Ken signed first, then yourself, and finally Jim.

"You're a fucking idiot, Bill." Jim laughed, as the three of you walked inside. "Everyone knows you're not supposed to give your own name on those sheets."

"Uh, right..." You scratched the back of your neck.

"Yeah, my go-to name of choice is Vladimir Putin." Ken replied. "I'm part Russian anyway, and the people sitting at the tables don't even notice it. Do you think I fit the role well?" He added, striking an authoritative pose.

"Whatever. At least it's more original than McLovin..." Jim said. "If you could choose a new name, what would it be, Bill?"

"I don't know." You shrugged your shoulders, having felt perfectly fine going by Bill for the past 21 years of your life. Not William, not Billy, just Bill Conway.

"You don't know? Ah, that's okay. We'll help you find an alias for future events. That is, of course, assuming Ken ropes us into coming to these stupid events again."

"Hey! I heard that!" Ken turned around, balling his fists.
11511.title: Bill Conway

choices: Ken gets the next phone number.
Too late! The show's about to start.
115112.content:
Thanks to hangovers and a slow morning, you three were one of the last to show up for the town hall. Most people had finished their refreshments and found a seat at one of the two dozen round tables in the center of a ballroom-esque auditorium. The tables were covered with lacy white cloth, small dishes, glasses and pitchers of iced tea, water, and lemonade. The stage at the center of the auditorium had a hardwood podium with microphone, and behind it lay a long table for political candidates and their family members to sit. By your estimate there were about 100 people at this event.

You picked up a brochure from the registration table, flipping through it as Ken led everyone to an empty table.

"It says the first introductions will take place in 10 minutes." You observed, showing the page to Ken. "Followed by the speeches, a break, and then the question and answer portion."

"No talent show? Not even a swimsuit portion?" Jim snorted.

"Good, plenty of time to get some names and numbers." Ken ignored Jim's wisecrack, glancing around at the other people in attendance. Sadly, most of these people were far older than desired, and predominantly men.

"Excuse me miss, is that a 'Save Child Soldiers' bracelet you're wearing?" Jim piped up, looking in the direction of a girl sitting at the table adjacent to yours.

The girl didn't appear any older than you three. She was cute, in a petite sort of way, with a meek demeanor and sleek brown hair. She wore designer glasses and had a bit of makeup around the eyes and cheeks. She was wearing a pink, sleeveless silk top, black denim trousers, ballet flats, and the SCS bracelet on her wrist. Her fingernails were painted red. She had with her a pen and notebook, as well as a brown leather purse placed below her chair on the ballroom carpet.

The girl looked at the bracelet, then at Jim, and smiled shyly. "Are you familiar with the group?"

To which Jim replied, as if he had practiced in front of a mirror, "Of course. Saving Child Soldiers is not the only humanitarian organization I work with, but I think it's admirable how they help the community and brighten the lives of such needy families in third-world countries."

"I totally agree!" Replied the girl, brushing a strand of hair behind her ear.

"My name is Ryan Ishikawa," Said Jim, confidently reaching out for a handshake. "I used to work for a charity that built homes for schoolchildren in Rwanda."

"Wow, it's certainly a pleasure to meet you Ryan." Answered the girl. "My name is Kirsten Bo. I wish my life was as interesting as yours, but I'm just a university student. I'm also the daughter and campaign manager for my father, Franklin Bo."

"Oh, so your father is running for mayor too?" Jim feigned enthusiasm in an award-winning display, as you watched on with interest. "Is he on stage right now? When can we listen to him speak?"

Kirsten sighed. "Unfortunately, we're running a pretty tight campaign, and we couldn't get enough money for my father to be invited. He's the centrist candidate, almost like a protest vote, you know? His day job is as an inventor, but on the weekends he goes around the town networking and getting contacts. It's a time-consuming effort. He couldn't be here today, so I'm here instead to gather notes about the other candidates. I'm really glad I came." She said, smiling at Jim before clearing her throat. She tapped her notebook with the pen. "Um... perhaps you could send us your information, so he can talk with you? I bet you have a lot of great stories to tell of homebuilding in Africa."

"Well, I'd give you my business card, but I really wasn't expecting anyone to care about what I do!" Jim said. "It's not every day I get to meet such a cute girl who shares an interest in helping the underprivileged." Meanwhile, you facepalmed. More cheese than a cheesecake.

"Aww, you're so sweet!" Kirsten blushed. She scribbled something on her notepad, tore off the piece, and handed it to Jim. "Here's my number. You can call at anytime."

"To schedule a meeting with your father?"

"Something like that!" Kirsten said coyly.

"Thanks very much, Kirsten Bo." Jim, said, tapping the buttons on the screen of his smartphone to add her as a contact.

"You're welcome, Ryan!" She beamed.

Jim turned around to receive your and Ken's full attention. You were desperately trying to stifle laughter, while Ken's jaw practically dropped through the table. Jim flicked the piece of paper containing the phone number between his fingers triumphantly. Jim grinned from ear to ear. "Gentlemen, the game is on!"
115112.title: Meeting the candidates.

choices: You notice someone strange in the back of the room...
1151122.content:
"Crap, there's no more time." You said, looking at the clock above the auditorium.

"Sorry dudes, not too many chicks to go around!" Jim whispered, the swagger clearly evident in his mood.

"Beginner's luck. Just wait until this is over, and I'll get twice as many as you, Ryan." Ken murmured.

"Keep on dreaming, Vladdy." Jim snickered.

The lights in the audience dimmed before refocusing on the stage. A balding man, dressed in a business-casual shirt and slacks, strode over to the microphone. In his hand were some sheets of paper, which he placed on the lectern and looked at occasionally while he spoke.

"Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for coming to the first annual Mayor's Collaborative Forum and Town Hall. The two candidates attending the debate today have been campaigning for the past few months, tirelessly gathering the needed signatures, donations, supporters, and contacts needed to win the distinguished office of mayor. In just a moment, they'll have the opportunity to introduce themselves. I'd also like to thank our sponsors for providing complementary snacks and drinks, local channel TVRN for broadcasting this live event, as well as the Hotel Claremont, for reserving this ballroom during the middle of the day. This is shaping up to be a fine event. Thank you for coming here, showing your support, and making your voice count. So, without further ado, I give you the speakers."

The audience gave a round of applause. Jim rolled his eyes, clapping extra loudly, thankful for the formalities to be over. Ken was looking around at the other people in the audience, eager to lay eyes (and something else, eventually) on the next attractive woman and catch up to Jim's early lead.

"Finders keepers on the chick with the sunhat. Third table up, sitting next to her mom." You heard Ken whisper to Jim.

"Oh, you mean Tits McGee over there?" Jim whispered back, drawing a reproachful stare from someone who overheard. "I noticed her 5 minutes ago. She's mine at the next break."

"Nu-uh. I called her first." Ken said.

"It doesn't work like that, dumbass!" Jim retorted icily. "What is this, fifth grade?"

"Just shut up, both of you!" You whispered, as a few members in the audience began hushing Jim and Ken's brewing argument. "If you get us kicked out of here we all lose. Be quiet and don't do anything stupid."

"Okay, mom..." Jim mumbled sardonically.
1151122.title: Too late! The show's about to start.

choices: You start to feel a little weird...
11511221.content:
The first candidate got up from the table, walked over to the podium, and adjusted the microphone downward to better accommodate his stocky, rotund frame.

"I thank you all for coming today," The man began, his deep voice rumbling in and around the loudspeakers. "My name is Adam Snow. I'm 43 years old, and am, since last July, married to a gorgeous wife and wonderful partner, whom I love with all my heart, Cassandra." He said, looking behind him at the woman who was sitting next to him at the table.

The woman, Cassandra Snow, may have been 37 years old, but excellent cosmetology and a few aesthetic procedures made her appearance competitive with that of someone ten years younger. Her face showed none of the wrinkles associated with aging, and her hair extended beyond her shoulders in a platinum-blonde sheen. The light revealed bright red lipstick, a gold necklace, and a white blouse with a plunging neckline. She was also wearing a light jacket to cover her arms, and her fingers were slender and topped off with an expensive diamond wedding ring. She wore a grey pencil skirt. It cut just above her knees, where tan pantyhose trailed downward to meet a matching pair of beige, wedge-heeled sandals.

"Dude..." Jim said, mesmerized with a deer- in-the-headlights facial expression. "Look at her jugs, Bill. Those things can't be real." You noted how much her breasts strained against the shirt she was wearing, creating greater cleavage than was probably needed for this occasion. "How much you want to bet they're fake, Bill?"

"How would we find out?" You replied. "They're suspect, to say the least. She looks like a trophy wife."

"Trophy wife? How about MILF?" He whispered. Ken glared at both of you in a reminder to keep voices down during the speech.

"Nah, it says in the brochure that the Snows don't have any children." You answered, pointing at a page with candidate biographies. "Hell, they've only been married for a few months."

"A few months and not even a baby bump." Jim remarked, shaking his head. "If I were Mr. Snow I wouldn't be wasting any time, if you know what I mean."

"Yeah, but you're not him. You're Jim. Or Ryan?" Grinning, you turned your attention back to the speakers.

"... And then Pete said, 'that's not a courtroom, that's my house!" Joked Adam Snow, eliciting scattered laughter from the audience. "To make a long story short, folks, I've had a lot of great successes serving the community, and if you re-elect me for mayor, you won't regret it. Thank you." Mr. Snow stepped down from the podium, wiped his brow, and strode back over to rejoin his wife at the table. He kissed her on the cheek as she clasped her hand over his on the tabletop. For just a split second, you and Cassandra made eye contact. She then glanced over other members of the audience.
11511221.title: Candidate introductions

choices: Skip to the end of the event.
115112211.content:
The bald man appeared over the lectern once again, Adam Snow having taken a seat next to his buxom wife back at the table on the stage.

"Thanks for your opening speech, Mr. Snow." He said. "Now, let's give our next candidate the opportunity to speak. Ms. Angelica Cortez was born in Argentina, moved to our country as a little girl, and became well educated at our very own Everton University. She holds a doctorate in political science and has written three books on the subject of minority representation in public schools. Without further ado, Ms. Cortez."

The audience gave another round of applause. Jim clapped with ironic enthusiasm, while Ken maintained a determined facial expression, evidently trying to even the score with Jim.

"Thank you, Mr. Brooks." Spoke Angelica into the microphone. Unlike her opponent, Angelica's voice was hard and authoritative, with a distinctive Latina accent. She commanded an aura of gravitas that flirted between professionalism and elitism. "I believe that our society has languished in complacency for too long. For too long, I say, the poor are being neglected and left on the streets. We have turned a collective blind eye to the disadvantaged, and we must do more..."

Jim poured another glass of lemonade, the sound of ice cubes clinking against each other breaking your and Ken's attention.

"Dude, can you be quiet for like three seconds?" Ken asked. "I'm trying to listen to the speech!"

"Look who suddenly cares about politics, Bill." Jim laughed, causing Ken's face to flush with anger. "This glass of lemonade could be a better candidate than that windbag on stage."

"Who cares, just be quiet." You reminded the group.

Angelica Cortez stood slightly taller than her opponent, Adam Snow, but only because of her heeled boots and above-average height. She wore a satin tunic underneath a navy blue, buttoned jacket. Her legs were covered by a matching blue straight-leg pants. Her fingernails were not painted, but she did have the slightest hint of makeup and lip gloss. Her skin color was darker than the others on stage, and her curly hair reached shoulder length and no more.

"... Which is why 46 percent of the public believes rehabilitation, not retribution, is the proper way to address crime in this city!" Angelica finished, resulting in more scattered applause from the audience. She gathered her own cards from the lectern before sitting back down at the table. Oddly enough, there was nobody sitting with her.

"What gives? Isn't this supposed to be a family event? The political candidates were supposed to bring their family members here, but Cortez didn't bring anyone." Jim said.

"That's because she doesn't have any." You answered, indicating again the biographies section of the political pamphlet. "35 years old, unmarried, no siblings, parents deceased."

"Sounds like a Manchurian candidate to me..." Jim mumbled, part conspiratorially.

"I don't see why not," Ken joined the conversation. "Why she has no family, I mean. She has the potential to look really attractive. It's just hidden beneath the restricting clothing and brisk personality."

"Yeah, and she's a fucking politician." Jim added. "Boss people around, sit in a nice cushy office all day. No need for sweating like a pig, loading and unloading pallets of suitcases at an airport."

"You mad bro?" Ken grinned, finding some amusement in Jim's desire to do anything except listen to another speech or be cooped up inside a cold room on a warm weekend day.

"Let's get on with it..." Jim said, rubbing his eyebrows. You merely smirked and waited for the next events to occur.
115112211.title: Angelica Cortez introduces herself next.

choices: A strange person overhears and has an odd device...
1151122112.content:
After being warned by security to keep the conversations down, you, Jim, and Ken had little to say in the wake of the next few sections of the debate. Adam Snow and Angelica Cortez exchanged arguments, fielded questions from the audience, and built their case on why they should be elected mayor. It was all rather boring and predictable, and it was all you could do to stay awake and scout out the room for potential chicks. There were a couple breaks in between, where you three split up to mingle with the other guests in the crowd. By the end of the event, which ended up being the middle of the afternoon, you three gathered numbers to tally the winner.
"So, who won today?" You asked, holding scraps of paper in your hands like poker cards.

"It wasn't Snow, and it wasn't Cortez," Jim smiled triumphantly. "It was Wong by a landslide!" He lined up four phone numbers on the table.

"Damn." Was all Ken could say. "You beat us. You and your damn charisma."

"How many of those were as Ryan?" You eyed the papers skeptically. "Or Douglas? Or Francois LeGrande the Third?" Recalling the now-infamous memory of Jim's failed attempt at wooing a French exchange student at school last month.

"Only that first one was Ryan." Jim said defensively. "You might not believe it, Bill, but the chicks dig a confident man. It's only natural that I won. Don't feel bad!" His grin was permanently plastered to his face. "So what do I win?"

Ken punched him in the shoulder. "Nothing, you idiot. Two of those numbers aren't even real. See, they only have six digits. I don't even need to be an apprenticing electrician to know that."

Jim did a double-take at the numbers. "Well, shit." You and Ken burst out laughing at Jim's premature gloating. "I demand a recount!"

"Fine," You said, again counting the legitimate numbers. "The results are in: Jim got two, Ken got one, and I got two. So it looks like Jim and I tied." You had struck up a conversation with a couple girls who attended your university; they were attending this debate for a course assignment. Actually, they were close acquaintances from a journalism course you had taken a few semesters back, as part of a group project, and you already had their numbers in your cell phone. Not that Jim or Ken needed to know, of course. It still counted as far as you were concerned.

"Wow, Ken got a number too?" Jim feigned mock surprise. "What was his name?"

"Very funny, Jim." Ken shook his head and smiled. "She was the sunhat girl. So I win by quality, not quantity unlike you two."

"Wins by quality, huh? We'll see about that once we put these numbers to the test." Jim retorted. "The best is yet to come!"
1151122112.title: Skip to the end of the event.

choices: It's the pizza guy, right on time.
A man wearing a ski mask and a trench coat?
11511221122.content:
Later that evening...

"I can't believe we wasted half a day going to that bogus political debate." Jim said, laying on the couch at your apartment. You each held a video game controller, your collective attention fixated on the TV screen, which displayed soldiers running through a jungle terrain, wielding large weapons and gunning each other down.

"Come on, it wasn't that bad of an idea." Ken said, still looking at the screen. "You got a couple phone numbers out of it at least. Plus, that Kristin chick looks pretty hot."

"Kirsten." Jim corrected him, "I tried calling her today and --- Headshot! --- she didn't answer."

"She could be canvassing the city, collecting signatures or something." You replied, remembering that Kirsten was pretty much the only dedicated campaign worker for her father's fledgling campaign. "Besides, aren't you supposed to wait a day or two before calling back?"

"Waiting is for suckers, Bill." Jim replied smoothly, grabbing a laser turret in the game. "What's that Latin phrase? Caveat emptor or whatever."

"It's carpe diem, retard." Ken scoffed. "Aww, no! Don't teabag my character!"

So you three continued to play video games, as the sun eventually dipped out of sight and it became evening. Jim suggested ordering a pizza, and after you all chipped in equal payments, you got two large pies for delivery. Before long a car pulled up to the sidewalk in front of the apartment complex. The doorbell buzzed (it didn't ring in Jim's apartment), and Jim paused the game and ran to the door.
11511221122.title: Later that evening.

115112211221.content:
Jim opened the door to find a lanky, teenage pizza delivery boy standing outside.

"Good evening, sir, here are your two extra-large pizzas."

Jim paid for the pizzas and tipped the delivery boy. He then placed the pizza boxes on the counter and got out some paper plates and napkins.

"Here you go, fellas, eat and be merry. If you're gonna take one of my beers, have the decency to leave my Scotch alone this time... Ken. And take a napkin okay? If you get grease on the couch I will kill you. Then I will kill your character in this video game. In that order. Got it?"

So you three spent the rest of the night hanging out at Jim's place, eating pizza, drinking beer, and playing videogames. What better way to spend a Saturday? As it got much later, you and decided to leave and get ready to go home. Since Ken and Jim were roommates (Jim's flat had limited space), you decided to get ready to go back to your own apartment. You took a shower, threw on the same clothes you were wearing before, and grabbed your car keys. You limited yourself on the beer this evening, of course, unlike your two friends, who didn't have to drive anywhere that night.

"Ugh," Jim said, sprawled out on the couch. "I feel so weird."

"Weird?" Ken said, now dressed in sweatpants and a Red Hot Chili Peppers t-shirt. "You're drunk. You've been drinking too much in the last 24 hours."

"Maybe, but this feels... weird." Jim said, still laying on the couch. "I feel... different for some reason." Changing the subject, in an attempt to get his mind off the sudden and inexplicable sense of 'oddness' overwhelming him, he said, "Look guys, this is loads of fun and all. I wouldn't have spent this Saturday with anyone else. But, why is beer so expensive? I'm gonna go broke at this rate."

"Beer is expensive because, otherwise, people like you would drink it all." Ken stated matter-of-factly. "What you need is sleep. We're all just... sleepy. Been having too much fun this weekend. That's all." You inferred that there was more to it than Ken said. Did Ken perceive what Jim was feeling on some level? An indescribable sensation of 'oddness', almost like 'otherness', if that could be applied to a personal feeling?

You shrugged your shoulders and yawned. "Thankfully I knew I'd be driving home tonight. Don't wait up for me." Since you three had crashed at your place last night, it was your car that you transported everyone around in today. The same car you'll be driving back in tonight, a full circle.

Jim was already asleep, and Ken was walking back into his room. All the lights out, you bid them good night and trudged in the darkness over to your car. It was an old, brown sedan but it got you from point A to B.

You arrived back at your place safely, it now being quite late and the streets less congested than earlier in the evening. After giving a halfhearted attempt at homework, you leaped into bed and fell asleep.
115112211221.title: It's the pizza guy, right on time.

Who do you swap with?

The wind has started to pick up, and you can see storm clouds approaching from the north. The few students outside walk quickly past you. Most of them have umbrellas.

"That's assuming we can get into your room," Jim mumbles. "Unless Linda has a copy of your keys?"

Shit. You hadn't thought about that. With the transformation and the disappearance of your old bodies, you don't have your dorm key or your student ID. You could maybe call campus police, but if nobody was in the room they wouldn't do a thing, no matter how loudly you insisted you were Bill's girlfriend. You consider rerouting toward Linda's dorm room but it's already too late. She's on the other side of campus where it's probably started raining. Lightning flashes over the University's film school.

"Let's hope," you say, which prompts an eye roll from Jim. "I hope you know what you're doing," says Ken, although he doesn't sound too hopeful. But despite your friends' lack of trust, somehow you feel confident that you'll make it through somehow. It might be Linda's athletic build. You can't help walking with her breezy stride, feeling her muscles tighten and her spine standing taut, resisting your inclination to slouch. You know if you wanted you could break into a mad dash and maintain speed for miles. You smile to yourself, remembering how Linda always badgered you about getting off your ass and working out with her. You always resisted, but now that your girlfriend's health is your own, you realize what a difference it makes in mood, determination, and a willingness to lead. "You had a point," you think, like Linda can hear you. "Sorry I doubted you."

All that changes once you enter the men's dorms. Walking through the lobby, you're jostled by a trio of bulky football types.
